source_course.name: Signals and Systems
source_course.academic_orientation: Theoretical foundations with applied engineering analysis
learning_objectives: Analyze signals in both time and frequency domains
Apply Fourier and Laplace transforms to characterize systems
Model and analyze LTI systems using convolution and transfer functions
Evaluate frequency response and system behavior using Bode plots
Understand sampling, modulation, and filtering principles
Assess stability and behavior of feedback systems
source_course.recommended_literature: A. V. Oppenheim and A. S. Willsky, Signals and Systems

matching_criteria.theoretical_depth: Strong mathematical foundation in transforms, system theory, and signal representations
matching_criteria.conceptual_scope: Core signals and systems concepts spanning continuous-time and frequency-domain analysis
matching_criteria.practical_component: Moderate, primarily analytical with supporting laboratory work
matching_criteria.tooling_or_methods: Analytical derivations, transform methods, block diagrams, frequency response analysis
matching_criteria.domain_specificity: Electrical and Computer Engineering signal analysis
matching_criteria.academic_rigor: High for undergraduate level, exam-driven with formal mathematical reasoning
matching_criteria.reasoning_basis: Alignment is evaluated based on overlap in core signal theory topics, mathematical rigor, and system analysis methodology

why_selected: Direct focus on signals and systems theory
Includes LTI systems and frequency response
reasoning.theoretical_alignment: Strong alignment in mathematical treatment of signals, systems, and transforms
reasoning.practical_alignment: Comparable analytical exercises, with lighter emphasis on formal examinations
gap_analysis: Less emphasis on formal, high-stakes written exams
Limited coverage of feedback stability compared to the source course
